evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The explanation of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident is robust against alternative causes and maintains validity despite potential defeaters.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was observed and documented in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA incident on 12-25 during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If the crew had clearly communicated and coordinated but the incident occurred due to other factors

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly documents a lack of communication and coordination among crew members during the pushback, as the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver did not speak up when the pushback passed the TRP (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions without questioning (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit transcript or recordings of communications; reliance on post-incident statements may introduce bias or incomplete information.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal incident.

assumptions: The described communication and coordination issues reflect failures in human factors and crew resource management
The incident context is comparable to typical CRM failure scenarios
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If the crew had explicit procedures and signals that were properly followed
If the incident was caused by external factors unrelated to crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12) shows a lack of effective communication and coordination among the crew, with missed warnings and assumptions leading to the pushback past the TRP and collision, consistent with human factors and crew resource management failures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent to which crew resource management protocols were established or followed; lack of detailed procedural context

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The environmental or marking deficiency must be resistant to common defeaters or counterarguments within the scope of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal inspection.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection context.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were missing, unclear, or otherwise deficient during the inspection on 12-25.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or observability of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters within the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal scope.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure fits the key features observed in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal scope.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing_737-8AS_9H-QAA_12-25:hist_t3_prefinal scope.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction in the aircraft during the incident
Maintenance records indicating failure
Sensor or system data showing control failure
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure of the Boeing 737-8AS aircraft; all evidence describes human actions and situational factors during pushback.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or exceptions within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback operations in the historical timeline prefinal phase.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.

defeaters: If the historical timeline records were found to be incomplete or missing the procedural deviation details
If the procedural deviation was documented elsewhere but not in the specified historical timeline prefinal records

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical timeline records (H1-H13) document the procedural deviation during pushback execution, including the sequence of events, personnel involved, and the location of the TRP, confirming the deviation is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback operations in the historical timeline prefinal phase.

assumptions: The key features for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback operations include the roles and procedures described in the evidence
The historical timeline prefinal phase corresponds to the described event and procedures
defeaters: If evidence showed the procedural deviation was due to an unrecognized or undocumented factor outside the known key features
If the TRP or operational procedures for this aircraft and phase were different than described
If the deviation was caused by equipment failure or external factors not aligned with the key features

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly describes the pushback operation involving the tug instructor and trainee, the known TRP location and clearance, and the deviation where the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier (H4). The procedural details and roles align with the key features of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA pushback operations in the prefinal phase (H1-H3, H9-H13).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about the adequacy of visual signals and communication during pushback, and the small size of the TRP, which may affect interpretation of alignment with key features.

defeaters: If the historical timeline records were found to be incomplete or missing the procedural deviation details
If the procedural deviation was documented elsewhere but not in the specified historical timeline prefinal records
